quoteFirst: “I forgot to let them know that I have a lady to dinner with me. Let cook do something extra, and tell Beacon to have the landau and pair at
quoteLast: to drive her back to Town to-night. Is Miss Holly asleep?”
title:
The Forsyte Saga, Volume II.
Indian Summer of a Forsyte
In Chancery
author: Galsworthy, John, 1867-1933

quoteFirst: She protested and took a lot of persuading; but he prevailed upon her and she let him clasp it about her neck and kiss her. After that--Good Lord! They spooned for about two hours and never even noticed the snow which had begun to fall, while I shivered along behind. About
quoteLast: they made a break-away and he left her at the park gates and went on down to his rooms. I put up for the night at the Hotel Gaythorne, just across the way, and kept a look-out, but there were no further developments until early this morning.
title: The Crevice
author: Burns, William J., 1861-1932; Ostrander, Isabel, 1883-1924; Grefé, Will, 1875-1957 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: We at once set out for the railway station, where the king was to arrive at
quoteLast: . Coretti, the father, smoked his pipe and rubbed his hands. "Do you know," said he, "I have not seen him since the war of 'sixty-six? A trifle of fifteen years and six months.
title: Cuore (Heart): An Italian Schoolboy's Journal
author: De Amicis, Edmondo, 1846-1908; Hapgood, Isabel Florence, 1850-1928 [Translator]

quoteFirst: "Well, last night I was going round about
quoteLast: to see that all the crew were in their beds. When I came to H, New Court, I found a devil of a row going on in Muggeridge's rooms--directly under Duncombe's, you know."
title: A Man's Man
author: Hay, Ian, 1876-1952; Flagg, James Montgomery, 1877-1960 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: the following day, the squadron hove in sight.
title: Naval songs and ballads
author: Firth, C. H. (Charles Harding), 1857-1936 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Had a pleasant chat in the evening; was informed about the watches which are reckoned from twelve at noon ringing every half hour till four, making what is called eight bells; then begins again. Retired to rest about
quoteLast: . Soon after being in my berth found considerable heaves 6 or 8 times, then still whilst I counted 20 or 25, then again heaving as before. This is occasioned by what are called the Swells.
title: A Journey to America in 1834
author: Heywood, Robert, 1786-1868

quoteFirst: Simply he cared nothing for it, nor, when his failure to get elected to the County Club occurred to him, did he care: it appeared to have happened, but it must have happened to some stranger. Sometimes, before the pink clock announced that it was
quoteLast: , he would leave the drawing-room and go to his library, to see whether in his books there was to be found anything that stimulated his reactions towards life. But they had no message: they were dumb or he was deaf.
title: An Autumn Sowing
author: Benson, E. F. (Edward Frederic), 1867-1940

quoteFirst: A long sitting of abstemious gentlemen was succeeded by a short sitting in the drawing-room, and then the bell sounded at ten, and the whole company trooped into the chapel for a slightly abbreviated evensong. Sometimes, this service was before dinner; otherwise, at its conclusion, round about
quoteLast: , the guests departed, for after this long devotional interlude, it was frankly impossible to resume a festive sociability. Already the cigarette-habit had made its footing in most houses, to the extent, anyhow, of a guest, if so decadently inclined, having opportunity of indulging his lust, but neither at Lambeth nor at Addington was there any parleying with the enemy.
title: Our Family Affairs, 1867-1896
author: Benson, E. F. (Edward Frederic), 1867-1940

quoteFirst: It was covered by an immense snow cornice, overhanging on the right, and, in order to avoid walking on it and incurring the risk of its breaking away, we had to keep well down to the left where the presence of ice occasionally necessitated the cutting of steps. Shortly after
quoteLast: we gained the spacious, snow-capped summit of the Mönch. A little way down on the north side, we found complete shelter from the wind which had now veered round and was blowing from the south.
title: The making of a mountaineer
author: Finch, George Ingle, 1888-1970

title: The letters of Queen Victoria, vol. 1, 1837-1843
author: Victoria, Queen of Great Britain, 1819-1901; Benson, Arthur Christopher, 1862-1925 [Editor]; Esher, Reginald Baliol Brett, Viscount, 1852-1930 [Editor]
